bibl.title: Despatch from Samuel S. Sevier to James D. Porter, January 18, 1887
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: So and Mar. 4/87
No. 50
Consulate General of the U.S. Monrovia Jany 18/87
Mr. S. S. Sevier-
To the Asst Secty of State.
Subject

Elucidation of complaint made against the Consular Agent at Elmina by the Vice Consul of the United States at Sierra Leone in Despatch No. 9 with inclosed copy No. 224 from the Vice Consul at Sierra Leone.
No 50.
Consulate General of the U.S. Monrovia Jany 18/87.
Hon. Jas D. Porter, Assistant Secty of State Washington D.C.

Sir: I take the honor to send this day an explaination of the Consular Agent at Elmina (Cape Coast Castle) against the complaint made by the Vice Consul at Sierra Leone of which your despatch No 9. instructed me to do. Hoping the explanation of the Consulor
Consular Agent will meet the approval of the Department of State,
I have the honor to be Sir Your Obedient Servant
Samuel S. Sevier Acting U.S. Consul Gen.
Inclosures
The Emisary to Mr Sevier No 30. Dec 20/86
Copy
United States Consular Agency at Elmina Dec 20, 1886
Hon Samuel S. Sevier United States Vice Consul Monrovia Liberia.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your despatch dated Monrovia Oct. 27/86 with the enclosed copy of a despatch No. 224 from the Department of State written by the Vice Consul Gen of Sierra Leone making complaints against me- The above arrived on 19th inst. -- In reply I
I reg to say,
1st that Jacob Smith was one of the crero of the big Giles Loving of Portland Mr Geo. Close master the vessel arrived here in distress being in a leaky condition.
2nd That men from ashore were put on board to keep the pumps going and the ships came to look after ship and cargo which the ship was lightened to discover the leak if possible.
3rd That said Jacob Smith was away during the night and stopped on shore for several days and nights after the report of the master
to this Consulate I send in search of said Jacob Smith.
4th That he was found in a disorderly condition in the street and the Police brought him to this Consulate, I ordered him to go on board the ship and found a canoe to take him on board.
5th That when he got to the beach or warf he refused to go off and after making some trouble the Police locked him up.
6th That the next day he was brought to this Consulate I tried my best to explain to him that he better go on board the ship and attend his

his work and that as soon as the ship was found to be unseaworthy they all would be paid off and sent home but if he did not do so he will be taken as a deserter this was in pressence of the master; he still refused to go on board the vessel, saying he had found some of his relations here and he is not an American and does not intend to go to the ship again nor to Boston and I had nothing to do with him.
7th That it was found out that the said Jacob Smith had smuggled
his personal property on shore long ago.
8th That after he had told me he was not an American subject and had nothing to do with United States Consulate I did not trouble myself any more about him.
9th That he Jacob Smith inlisted himself with the British Government out here.
10th That after some months he employed a Lawyer to sue the Captain for his wages- the Lawyer finding it was a bad case and that he Jacob Smith did
did not tell him the truth gave it up.
Hoping the above explanation will be satisfactory.
I have the honor to be Sir your obedient Servant
G. E. Emnsary U.S. Consular Agent.
